reviews.text: Cameron, somewhat contra this initiative, also loves weapons, vehicles, vehicles as weapons, and what it looks like when those things destroy a body. On which front Way of Water delivers far above its predecessor, or for that matter any animated movie.
reviews.author: Nick Newman

reviews.text: The 3-D special effects remain exceptional, but the screenplay is better this time, with a storyline more emotionally engaging than in the original. When people and critters die, we feel it this time.
reviews.author: Randy Myers

reviews.text: While The Way of Water can feel a bit like a preachy David Attenborough programme and is easily half an hour too long, the 3D is absolutely breathtaking.
reviews.author: Dulcie Pearce

reviews.text: A sometimes surreal, always spectacular sensory hit with an undertow of gentle emotion, an overflow of ambition, and a pleasingly earnest thematic thrust.
reviews.author: Kevin Harley

reviews.text: An extraordinary visual spectacle that can’t compare on the narrative side — although, to be fair, that’s a mighty high bar.
reviews.author: Tim Grierson

reviews.text: The most mesmeric experience I’ve had in a theater this year, perhaps in a few years.
reviews.author: Kyle Pinion

reviews.text: It’s a leap beyond even what he pulled off with the first film, a phantasmagorical, fully immersive waking dream of a movie in which something impossible is happening on-screen at almost every moment.
reviews.author: Nick De Semlyen

reviews.text: ‘The most dangerous thing about Pandora,’ someone muses sagely at one point, ‘is that you grow to love it too much.’ Jim Cameron disagrees. He can’t love this place enough – and it’s infectious.
reviews.author: Philip De Semlyen

reviews.text: It’s still more of a spectacle than a movie. But as spectacles go, it’s a big one.
reviews.author: Bill Goodykoontz

reviews.text: Never doubt Big Jim! Avatar: The Way of Water is an indescribable visual spectacle. It's not just a blockbuster done to perfection but an experience that captures the magic of going to the movies.
reviews.author: David Gonzalez

reviews.text: Whoever thought that a 10-foot-tall blue alien would be such a sight for sore eyes?
reviews.author: Johnny Oleksinski

reviews.text: Cameron pulls you down so deep, and sets you so gently adrift, that at times you don’t feel like you’re watching a movie so much as floating in one.
reviews.author: Justin Chang

reviews.text: It’s time well spent for a movie set in deep space that turns out to be a free-flowing whale of a tale.
reviews.author: Peter Howell

reviews.text: As a story, The Way of Water disappoints, even as its visuals overwhelm.
reviews.author: Isaac Feldberg

reviews.text: ... A classic piece of franchise-elongation, in which nothing meaningful happens or important changes, and all the pieces are returned to their original positions, ready for the next instalment.
reviews.author: Robbie Collin

reviews.text: It sets the bar even higher for sci-fi epics. The movie's technical achievements and story surpass the first Avatar film. Expect to be immersed in a visually stunning world that has a lot to say about protection of families and the environment.
reviews.author: Carla Hay

reviews.text: If Cameron’s worldbuilding is exhausting, it also has an epic sincerity far from the lazy cash grab of most sequels. Lazy Cameron is not.
reviews.author: Danny Leigh

reviews.text: The Way of Water is the wave of the future, rolling in whether you like it or not.
reviews.author: Stephanie Zacharek

reviews.text: At 192 minutes, The Way of Water is less of a narrative film and more an endless tech demo one might expect to endure in purgatory.
reviews.author: Christopher Machell

reviews.text: This sequel is tremendous fun, even bigger and better than the original, but by golly it will test your bladder.
reviews.author: Brian Viner

reviews.text: Cameron’s all-encompassing style has a way of making other blockbusters feel small, vague. The Way of Water, in line with his best work, is more affecting for knowing its audience, for digging into primal feelings about being misunderstood.
reviews.author: K. Austin Collins

reviews.text: Overwritten, when it isn’t underwritten. Overwrought. Overblown. I’m over it.
reviews.author: Adam Kempenaar

reviews.text: Avatar: The Way of Water transforms from simple wonder to something truly jaw-dropping.
reviews.author: Richard Whittaker

reviews.text: True movie magic. The Way of Water is a visual marvel loaded with groundbreaking technical feats that always feel in service of character and world-building.
reviews.author: Perri Nemiroff

reviews.text: Creatively speaking, [it's] of a piece with its predecessor, a would-be epic of boundary-pushing digi-grandeur in service of Pocahontas-style us-vs-them mush.
reviews.author: Nick Schager

reviews.text: A meticulous world-building as astonishing and enveloping as anything we've ever seen on screen — until that crown is passed, inevitably, in December 2024, the projected release date for Avatar 3.
reviews.author: Leah Greenblatt

reviews.text: It's a gorgeous visual treat, a testament to the artistry and attention to detail of Cameron and his effects crew, but if you're looking for anything else from it, you'll be left sorely disappointed.
reviews.author: Kyle Anderson

reviews.text: For The Way of Water, the decadence is more than enough -- for cinemas that have been starved of authentic spectacle, finally, here’s a gorgeous three-course meal of it.
reviews.author: David Sims

reviews.text: Not for nothing do the combatants in this epic about planetary warfare feel like they stand a little straighter, swing a little harder, cheer a little louder because they take after the filmmaker’s passion, and not just how deep corporate pocketbooks go.
reviews.author: David Lynch

reviews.text: The Way of Water insists that times haven’t changed; it is heedless of contemporary industry undulations. That swaggering energy is, in large part, what makes the film such a pleasure to watch.
reviews.author: Richard Lawson

reviews.text: For now, the only thing that matters is that after 13 years of being a punchline, “going back to Pandora” just became the best deal on Earth for the price of a movie ticket.
reviews.author: David Ehrlich

reviews.text: There is beauty everywhere you look, from the spectacle provided by nature’s creations, the tactile sense you get from the skin and hair of humans and other natural life, and the emotional expressions of strength and sensitivity.
reviews.author: Todd McCarthy

reviews.text: It's like a travelogue for a place James Cameron clearly wants to live in and that he helps sell you on wanting to live in... It's an experience this year that I have not had in a movie theater and that I'm very eager to get back to.
reviews.author: Eric Goldman

reviews.text: Cameron's limitations as storyteller remain as crystal clear as the water. But one does not look to Avatar for narrative sophistication.
reviews.author: A.A. Dowd

reviews.text: James Cameron has more than equaled the visual spectacle bar he set for himself, once again creating a world you might feel sad you can’t actually visit.
reviews.author: Luke Y. Thompson

reviews.text: If the first Avatar is remarkable because it shows us wondrous lands nothing like our own, The Way of Water is remarkable because it shows us that this world is, in fact, very much like our own.
reviews.author: Bilge Ebiri

reviews.text: When Cameron’s film calms down, and the stunning imagery that cinematographer Russell Carpenter has created with the film’s enormous visual-effects team can linger for a while, its imagination and scope can occasionally feel quite magical.
reviews.author: William Bibbiani

reviews.text: Even with its flaws, The Way of Water is an immersive, gorgeous cinematic journey through Pandora.
reviews.author: Maria Lattila

reviews.text: This wildly entertaining film isn't a retread of Avatar, but a film in which fans can pick out thematic and even visual elements of Titanic, Aliens, The Abyss, and The Terminator films.
reviews.author: Brian Tallerico

reviews.text: Does exactly what is expected from it even if it eventually fails to move the narrative beyond the obvious "good guys Vs stereotypical villains" narrative.
reviews.author: Linda Marric

reviews.text: Avatar The Way of Water is a prime example of style over substance. It astonishing piece of filmmaking with immense visuals and action but the plot is weak and overstuffed.
reviews.author: Sarah Cook

reviews.text: The Way of Water is a stunning and somewhat mind-blowing visual experience. Story-wise, it is about what you expect, but the world-building is monumental. Cameron has truly delivered an epic blockbuster.
reviews.author: Austin Burke

reviews.text: I can’t say that I cared all that much about its story, its themes, or its characters, but its unimpeachable effects work made it feel like I’d locked eyes with the future.
reviews.author: Clarisse Loughrey

reviews.text: Proves more frustrating than waiting 13 years for the sequel to Avatar. The new film introduces way too many new characters and doesn't serve any of them.
reviews.author: Fred Topel

reviews.text: The post-Pandora blues are back, and they can only be cured with the cause: Avatar The Way of Water is ultra big-screen escapism.
reviews.author: Cameron Frew

reviews.text: James Cameron's epic sequel builds out his sci-fi world, but with a more 3D story than before
reviews.author: Ali Shutler

reviews.text: An emotionally charged outing that again dips into themes of colonization while adding environmental issues and relatable family drama.
reviews.author: Brian Truitt

reviews.text: The only part of me that was moved was my eyeballs.
reviews.author: Owen Gleiberman

reviews.text: “Avatar: The Way of Water” is a cinematic roller coaster that’s so breathtaking, awe-inspiring, and innovative beyond comprehension, you forget that you’re witnessing history.
reviews.author: Nate Adams

reviews.text: Cameron has, once again, knocked it so far out of the park that it’s going to take years to retrieve the ball. It is, quite simply, one the best-looking, most deeply felt Hollywood blockbusters we’re likely to experience for some time.
reviews.author: Siddhant Adlakha

reviews.text: Avatar: The Way of Water is a clear improvement on its predecessor and, though its story isn’t breaking new ground, its jaw-dropping visuals make this an irresistible return to Pandora.
reviews.author: Tom Jorgensen

reviews.text: Ultimately, it’s the sincerity of Cameron’s belief in this fantastical world he’s created that makes it memorable.
reviews.author: David Rooney

reviews.text: Avatar 2, even with its faults, manages to showcase exactly why James Cameron...understands how to create wonder and magic and respects special effects as a medium in the same way he respects pushing the bounds of underwater filming.
reviews.author: Kate Sánchez

reviews.text: The Way of Water is still that rarest of things: a transportive blockbuster that voyages across new frontiers, all of which are fully realised in resplendent detail.
reviews.author: Yasmin Omar

reviews.text: While other movies might feel empty by relying on their visuals, The Way of Water emotes through them. Did I care for any of the characters (or know their names)? Nope. But it's an entertaining epic visual magnum opus that has to be seen in theaters.
reviews.author: Karl Delossantos

reviews.text: The floatingly bland plot is like a children’s story without the humour; a YA story without the emotional wound; an action thriller without the hard edge of real excitement.
reviews.author: Peter Bradshaw

reviews.text: Perhaps the most immersive moviegoing experience ever, I could get lost in the world of Pandora all day... or at least for 3 hours and 12 minutes.
reviews.author: Joey Morona

reviews.text: James Cameron’s high-tech spectacle succumbs to simplistic storytelling, shallow characterization, and a complete lack of engagement past its arduous artifice. It’s a disappointingly subpar sequel.
reviews.author: Eric Marchen

reviews.text: It favours style over substance. But when that style is so impeccably crafted, it's hardly an issue. You came here to be dazzled and dazzled you shall be. A masterclass in spectacle filmmaking.
reviews.author: Doug Jamieson

reviews.text: Avatar: The Way of Water feels like a fresh start for this series, as Cameron address the weaknesses of the first film, improve the script and characters, while also creating one of the most extraordinary experiences one can have at the theaters.
reviews.author: Ross Bonaime

reviews.text: James Cameron’s sequel is a truly dazzling cinematic experience that will have you floating on a blockbuster high.
reviews.author: Lindsey Bahr

reviews.text: The Way of Water is yet another leap forward in big screen spectacle, this time with even more feeling.
reviews.author: Jon Negroni

reviews.text: That The Way of Water is engaging nevertheless is a grand testament to Cameron’s abilities — as an immersive spectacle that no other medium could hope to replicate, it’s unlike anything we’ve seen since, well, probably the first Avatar.
reviews.author: Michael Nordine

reviews.text: Avatar: The Way of Water struggles under the weight of thirteen years of expectations and fails to be anything other than mediocre when it comes to anything other than the visuals.
reviews.author: Kaitlyn Booth

reviews.text: A feat of coldly-precise engineering, but not a good movie.
reviews.author: David Jenkins

reviews.text: The Way of Water is overlong and stretched thin on story, but the Avatar sequel is beautiful, with lush world-building and characters that add depth.
reviews.author: Mae Abdulbaki

reviews.text: James Cameron's Mega-Sequel Is An Overstuffed And Exciting Adventure.
reviews.author: Chris Evangelista

reviews.text: A technical marvel unlike anything I have ever seen before. Fortunately, Cameron also manages to bind us to the characters a little bit better in his return to Pandora. As far as blockbuster spectacle goes, this is simply incomparable.
reviews.author: Jimmy Cage

reviews.text: Watching "The Way of Water" is seeing the future of big blockbuster movies where the CGI is so crisp and beautiful (especially with 3D) that it's impossible for the eye to not think it's real.
reviews.author: Jason Guerrasio

reviews.text: James Cameron always pushes the envelope. This time, he has sealed himself inside. Frankly, if the "Avatar" films continue in this vein, Cameron’s intent to go out making as many as three more of them represents a truly depressing directorial epitaph.
reviews.author: Nick Rogers

reviews.text: Those who weren’t on the “Avatar” train the first time around should give Cameron a second chance.  “The Way of Water” is a glorious spectacle.
reviews.author: Laura Clifford

reviews.text: Words don't do Avatar: The Way of Water justice. While this film has all the makings of a once-in-a-lifetime theatrical experience, audiences should relish in the fact that there is much more to come.
reviews.author: Liam Crowley

reviews.text: It's a technical marvel, but that only goes so far if it didn't have more to offer. Fortunately, the time spent developing the first of several sequels has paid off, as this is a supremely entertaining adventure that is bigger and better than the first.
reviews.author: Aaron Neuwirth

reviews.text: It's certainly a visual masterpiece that's often beautiful to behold, but one that doesn't always have the substance to go with its considerable style.
reviews.author: Ian Sandwell

reviews.text: A visually stunning, cinematic adventure, that welcomes fans back to Pandora with open arms delivering both action and heart -- in a way too long package. Similar plot to Avatar, but dives deeper into the story and characters. Avatar fans will eat it up!
reviews.author: Tessa Smith

reviews.text: Director James Cameron's epic sequel has a lot to pack in: it's a decent sci-fi blockbuster, a visual effects masterclass, and the best nature documentary you'll ever see.
reviews.author: Richard Trenholm

reviews.text: Very much feels like a decade’s worth of accumulated ideas crammed into a single film.
reviews.author: Matt Singer

reviews.text: It is no exaggeration to say that this is one of the most technically impressive films ever made...a spectacular achievement, an epic homecoming in the most affectionate way.
reviews.author: Kevin L. Lee

reviews.text: "The Way of Water" is the magic of movies made manifest, a three-hour-plus epic that brings us to a new world and makes it thrillingly tactile in ways that no other film has done before. In other words: James Cameron has done it again.
reviews.author: Dan Bayer

reviews.text: For all the genuine thrills provided by its pioneering pageantry, Way of Water ultimately leaves you with a soul-nagging query: What price entertainment?
reviews.author: Keith Uhlich

synopsis: Set more than a decade after the events of the first film, "Avatar: The Way of Water" begins to tell the story of the Sully family (Jake, Neytiri, and their kids), the trouble that follows them, the lengths they go to keep each other safe, the battles they fight to stay alive, and the tragedies they endure.
